ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I developed a greater discipline in the Hebrew language, particularly with grammar.
Improving in Hebrew listening, reading, writing, and speaking skills.

I learned how to conjugate in the passive tense for a variety of verb families, as well as gaining more experience in speaking, writing, and comprehending Modern Hebrew. I expanded my vocabulary and got more comfortable in conversation as well.
I continued my progress in learning Hebrew. The Hebrew department at Yale is really solid.

Hebrew 140 strengthened my grammar, listening skills, writing skills and speaking skills immensely. We learned the remaining binyanim (verb conjugations) in their active and passive forms, learned many new nouns, verbs and adjectives and engaged heavily with Israeli culture. There was great application of the vocabulary to the videos, stories and other mediums we explored in the course.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Strength: constant work is put into developing mastery without it being overwhelming.

Perhaps the Jamboard feature of the in-person activities could be used a bit less.

Strengths: Sections with the TF were great, and there were some very good discussions in class. The videos and journal prompts were also very engaging. 
Weaknesses: It was really hard to memorize vocabulary and verbal structures, but this may have been due to the online format.

I greatly enjoyed this course and looked forward to our meetings three times a week. The mix of assignment types and the structure of the course were very helpful to my learning, and I appreciated the consistent, concrete, and swift feedback on assignments.

The only weakness I would identify is that I felt that I did not really retain the vocabulary/verb forms when we moved from unit to unit, simply because I was not forced to use them consistently. But overall I felt the course was very strong and I did go and review all of the material before exams, which helped.
I thought some of the work seemed repetitive and at times a bit too much, but perhaps that's a symptom of online learning that won't repeat in future semesters.

Hebrew 140 is extremely strong in the breadth of things that it covers and the bluntness in which it does so. At some point, there is no more messing around and you just sit down and learn the verb conjugations and whole lot of new vocabulary, and that is good. I feel as though the strong vocabulary background is the driving force behind the course. The professor, Orit, is kind and caring and is very good at teaching the material and answering any relevant questions about the linguistic origin of the Shoreshim or words. The course also was very good in its consistency, as there was good structure to the week's assignments meaning that certain days were always geared towards certain types of learning (writing, listening, speaking, grammar, etc).

I do wish that there were a bit more culture, though there was a lot, I just love the culture. I think this class would've been even better in person.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I believe having asynchronous work was a big plus of this course. It allowed me to do the necessary work on my own time.
Breakout rooms were great! However, there was not enough material to learn and review verbal structures.

As previously mentioned, the asynchronous assignments were a nice change of pace while still including interaction with my classmates. I appreciated the usage of Google Docs for our writing assignments so there was nothing to "submit" and being able to record my speaking assignments through Canvas/Panopto. The Jamboards during class time were a lot of fun, as were the Kahoot quizzes, but my internet bandwidth sometimes struggled to open the applications while still running Zoom.

It was the best it could possibly be. It was nice to have a 1 on 1 section with Naama during the week and I though the asynchronous learning days were a good break from Zoom seminars which can get tedious (it is always good to have structured and unstructured time to learn a language).

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes, this is a great course if you'd like to develop your Hebrew vocabulary and grammar.
Yes, if they want to continue on their journey for Hebrew!

I highly recommend all courses in the Hebrew program - all of the instructors are excellent and the courses are well-organized and engaging. I also really encourage any student who completes L3 to take this course as it is very much a continuation of L3 and gives a lot of reinforcement plus material that simply can't be covered in one semester.
I would recommend taking Hebrew. The department is solid and Orit is a great instructor.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: We had asynchronous activities to complete, which involved both individual and somewhat cooperative work.
Two "asynchronous" class days/week which involved participation in typed or recorded discussions over Canvas
There was, in addition to the virtual seminar, asynchronous learning on Tuesday and Thursday as well as a discussion section with teaching fellow, Naama Omri, once a week.
